column1: Woburn ( WOO-bərn) is a city in Middlesex County
column4: 120 at the 2010 census. Woburn is located 9 miles (14 km) north of Boston

column1: Woburn was first settled in 1640 near Horn Pond
column2: a primary source of the Mystic River
column3: and was officially incorporated in 1642. At that time the area included present day towns of Woburn
column6: and parts of Stoneham and Wilmington.  In 1740 Wilmington separated from Woburn. In 1799 Burlington separated from Woburn; in 1850 Winchester did so

column1: Woburn got its name from Woburn
column2: Bedfordshire.  Woburn played host to the first religious ordination in the Americas on Nov. 22
column3: 1642. Rev. Thomas Carter was sworn in by many of the most prominent men of New England including John Cotton
column4: minister of the First Church of Boston
column5: Richard Mather minister of the First Church of Dorchester
column6: and Capt. Edward Johnson co-founder of the church and town of Woburn. Johnson is regarded as "the father of Woburn."  He served as the first town clerk
column7: represented the town in the Massachusetts General Court
column8: made the first map of Massachusetts
column9: and wrote the first history of the colony.

column1: Middlesex Superior Courthouse moved to TradeCenter 128 business campus in 2008.
The final phase of construction is completed on TradeCenter 128 business campus in 2010.
Woburn Police Officer John B. Maguire was killed in the line of duty while responding to an armed robbery on December 26
Massachusetts Biotechnology Council awarded Woburn the platinum-level "Bio-Ready community" designation in 2011.
Woburn was the scene of a high-profile water contamination crisis.  During the mid to late 1970s
column2: the local community became concerned over the high incidence of childhood leukemia and other illnesses
column3: particularly in the Pine Street area of east Woburn. After high levels of chemical contamination were found in City of Woburn's Wells G and H in 1979
column4: some members of the community suspected that the unusually high incidence of leukemia
column6: and a wide variety of other health problems were linked to the possible exposure to volatile organic compounds in the groundwater pumped from wells G and H.

column2: a number of citizens whose children had developed or died from leukemia filed a civil lawsuit against two corporations
column3: W. R. Grace and Company and Beatrice Foods. Grace's subsidiary
column5: and Beatrice were suspected of contaminating the groundwater by improperly disposing of trichloroethylene (TCE)
column6: perchloroethylene (perc or PCE) and other industrial solvents at their facilities in Woburn near wells G and H.

column1: In a controversial decision over what many considered a bungled trial Judge Walter Jay Skinner ruled that the jurors should answer questions that they and many others considered confusing. Beatrice was acquitted and Grace only paid $8 million
column2: a third of which went to  the lawyers and lawyer fees. A United States Environmental Protection Agency report later found Beatrice and Grace responsible for the contamination.

column1: A book titled A Civil Action was written about the case by Jonathan Harr. In 1998 the book was turned into a movie starring John Travolta and Robert Duvall
column2: also titled A Civil Action. The film was largely filmed in nearby Bedford and Lexington
column3: with only a few shots on location in Woburn.

column2: -71.152060).  It is bordered by the towns of Wilmington

column1: Woburn features a humid continental climate
column2: similar to those of many of the other Boston suburban areas. It features moderately cold winters
column3: but not usually as bad as the ones around The Great Lakes Regions or Southern Canada
column4: or even Northern New England. Nonetheless
column5: it features occasional 'arctic blasts' which can easily drop the temperature below zero. Spring generally starts out cool
column7: often with snow still on the ground. However
column8: it quickly begins to rapidly warm to around 75 degrees by the time summer begins. Summers are generally warm or hot & often accompanied with humidity
column9: though not nearly as bad as cities in The Midwest & Mid-Atlantic
column10: and even Rhode Island. Temperatures often top in the 80s
column11: but when an Atlantic low comes
column12: temperatures may fail to rise out of the 60s. High pressure from the Gulf of Mexico
column13: occasionally brings much hotter conditions with temperatures sometimes topping near 100
column14: though this is fairly rare and only happens so often. Falls are generally crisp
column15: but start out warm with temperature highs around 70 & lows around 50. Quickly things cool
column16: and it feels and looks like winter with temperatures around 40 usually towards the end. Like most of the region
column17: temperatures can vary widely in the span of a day.

column1: The Woburn Business Association (WBA) is a membership organization consisting of companies located in Woburn
column2: Massachusetts. Memberships are also available to those firms who are situated elsewhere
column3: but do business in Woburn.  The purpose of the WBA is to promote and protect Business Interests in the City of Woburn and provide Networking Services for the Business Community.The WBA Board of Directors meets monthly to develop policy and provide direction for the Association. The Executive Committee meets periodically
column5: to review important issues and make recommendations to the Board regarding WBA policy.  The WBA accomplishes its work through committees of WBA members and representatives of the Woburn community. The membership is encouraged to actively participate on these committees.

column1: The Woburn Redevelopment Authority is an independent municipal urban renewal authority established by the City of Woburn in 1961
column2: in accordance with Massachusetts General Laws Chapter 121B.  The Authority is governed by five members
column3: four of whom are appointed by the Mayor
column4: and one by the Governor.  The WRA functions as the City's community development agency
column5: under an agreement with the City of Woburn executed in July 2000.Companies based in Woburn include Boston Acoustics
